Generation I.Red: The infant rarely ventures out of its mother's protective pouch until it is 3 years old.
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: The infant rarely ventures out of its mother's protective pouch until it is 3 years old.
Generation I.Yellow: Raises its young in its belly pouch. Won't run from any fight to keep its young protected.
Generation I.Stadium: The female raises its young in its belly pouch for around three years. The young is taken out once it learns to find food.

Generation II.Gold: If it is safe, the young gets out of the belly pouch to play. The adult keeps a close eye on the youngster.
Generation II.Silver: To protect its young, it will never give up during battle, no matter how badly wounded it is.
Generation II.Crystal: To avoid crushing the baby it carries in its pouch, it always sleeps standing up.
Generation II.Stadium 2: If it is safe, the young gets out of the belly pouch to play. The adult keeps a close eye on the youngster. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) To protect its young, it will never give up during battle, no matter how badly wounded it is. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: If you come across a young Kangaskhan playing by itself, you must never disturb it or attempt to catch it. The baby Pok é mon 's parent is sure to be in the area, and it will become violently enraged at you.
Generation III.Sapphire: If you come across a young Kangaskhan playing by itself, you must never disturb it or attempt to catch it. The baby Pok é mon 's parent is sure to be in the area, and it will become violently enraged at you.
Generation III.Emerald: If you come across a young Kangaskhan playing by itself, never try to catch it. The baby's parent is sure to be in the area, and it will become violently enraged.
Generation III.FireRed: The female raises its offspring in a pouch on its belly. It is skilled at attacking using Comet Punch .
Generation III.LeafGreen: The infant rarely ventures out of its mother's protective pouch until it is three years old.

Generation IV.Diamond: It raises its offspring in its belly pouch. It lets the baby out to play only when it feels safe.
Generation IV.Pearl: It raises its offspring in its belly pouch. It lets the baby out to play only when it feels safe.
Generation IV.Platinum: It raises its offspring in its belly pouch. It lets the baby out to play only when it feels safe.
Generation IV.HeartGold: If it is safe, the young gets out of the belly pouch to play. The adult keeps a close eye on the youngster.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: To protect its young, it will never give up during battle, no matter how badly wounded it is.

Generation V.Black: It raises its offspring in its belly pouch. It lets the baby out to play only when it feels safe.
Generation V.White: It raises its offspring in its belly pouch. It lets the baby out to play only when it feels safe.
Generation V.Black 2: It raises its offspring in its belly pouch. It lets the baby out to play only when it feels safe.
Generation V.White 2: It raises its offspring in its belly pouch. It lets the baby out to play only when it feels safe.

Generation VI.X: It raises its offspring in its belly pouch. It lets the baby out to play only when it feels safe.
Generation VI.Y: If it is safe, the young gets out of the belly pouch to play. The adult keeps a close eye on the youngster.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: If you come across a young Kangaskhan playing by itself, you must never disturb it or attempt to catch it. The baby Pokémon's parent is sure to be in the area, and it will become violently enraged at you.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: If you come across a young Kangaskhan playing by itself, you must never disturb it or attempt to catch it. The baby Pokémon's parent is sure to be in the area, and it will become violently enraged at you.

Generation VII.Sun: Mega Kangaskhan's strength derives from the mother's happiness about her child's growth. Watching it grow up keeps her spirits high.
Generation VII.Moon: Thanks to Mega Evolution, its child grows. But as the child is good only at fighting and nothing else, its mother feels uneasy about its future.
Generation VII.Ultra Sun: The explosive energy the child is bathed in causes temporary growth. The mother is beside herself with worry about it.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: When the mother sees the back of her Mega-Evolved child, it makes her think of the day when her child will inevitably leave her.
Generation VII.Let's Go Pikachu: Its child has grown rapidly, thanks to the energy of Mega Evolution. Mother and child show off their harmonious teamwork in battle.
Generation VII.Let's Go Eevee: Its child has grown rapidly, thanks to the energy of Mega Evolution. Mother and child show off their harmonious teamwork in battle.

Generation VIII.Sword: Although it's carrying its baby in a pouch on its belly, Kangaskhan is swift on its feet. It intimidates its opponents with quick jabs.
Generation VIII.Shield: There are records of a lost human child being raised by a childless Kangaskhan.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: It raises its offspring in its belly pouch. It lets its baby out to play only when it feels safe to do so.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It raises its offspring in its belly pouch. It lets its baby out to play only when it feels safe to do so.

Generation IV.HeartGold: Rock Tunnel Safari Zone Morning Day (Wasteland, default)
Generation IV.SoulSilver: Rock Tunnel Safari Zone Morning Day (Wasteland, default)

Generation VIII.Expansion Pass: Warm-Up Tunnel Training Lowlands ( Wanderer ) Max Lair ( Dynamax Adventure )
